title.narrative: Satellite and Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Remote Sensing Applications contributing to the creation of ecologically sustainable food and water management systems

description.narrative: The TMT training aims to provide an innovative use of Remote Sensing and UAV in the fields of agriculture, forestry and water ,considering the national needs. Where, it combines a wide range of skills, education and professional experience to develop new collaborations, improve existing capacity, and widen stakeholder involvement in Jordan.

participating-org.narrative: The University of Jordan (UJ) - School of Agriculture

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Credit: Field data collection in Ajloun Forest Reserve- Jordan
TMT course - University of Jordan
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. description.narrative: Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period. + In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
Both the Dutch and the Jordanian partners were content with the output of the project. The project evaluation with a response rate = 81% showed that more than 75 % of the participants agreed or strongly agreed with the organizational, the duration of the project, the learned knowledge, and how the project helped to increase the potential of inclusive development, and future collaboration opportunities. The project support survey with a response rate = 90 % showed that more than 80% agreed that the amount and the provided support from the staff members by the ITC during the different phases of the project and the UJ in the case studies was about right and good respectively. Besides, the participants highly valued the coordination, the field work and the UAV implementation part in the project. Please find attached the complete evaluation of the project translated to English.
Remote sensing using satellite images and UAVs is a promising technique to evaluate, monitor and conserve forests and agriculture. By using these techniques, we can scale-up forest and agriculture mapping and monitoring activities to larger areas. The TMT provided the opportunity to broaden the knowledge and skills of 22 members from 5 relevant organizations and one university in Jordan through the intensive training course, the implementation and the provided support by the specialists. This can be seen clearly not only by the implemented ongoing case studies in the project such as case study 1 where more data to be collected in summer 2021, and case study 4 where the inspection will be done regularly using the UAV, but also by including the knowledge in the research activities and university curricula.
Furthermore, the webinar helped increasing the awareness of the innovative technology, paved the way to create an enabling environment for UAVs in Jordan, and brought different stakeholders and users together for further collaboration.
**Lessons learned:**
- To increase the number of practical and discussions sessions in training. Participants found the sessions very useful for a better understanding of theoretical knowledge. - Using real examples and sample data from the same country increased the stimulation and the engagement of the participants in the training. - The importance of the harmonization and the teamwork between the project partners (UT and UJ) - Continuous communication between the UT and UJ, and the UT and the participants from the different organizations. - Continuous support and supervision between the UT and the other participants increased the motivation and improved the outputs - Taking early action to mitigate and adapt the unexpected changes in the project.
**Recommendations for post project period:**
- Continuous contact and collaboration with the participants especially with the UJ - Coordinate and collaborate with relevant institutions and stakeholders at the local and regional level

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
All the project's proposed phases have been implemented and completed, with some deviations from the actual plan as described in the previous sections. Besides, the project was extended for five months, including the standard Budget Neutral Extension (BNE) for three months. Despite these challenges, we managed to mitigate the impact of unforeseen factors and achieved the project objectives
**The following outcomes have been achieved in the project:**
1. Preparation phase– completed. Three staff members of ITC prepared the course materials and tailored it and fine-tuned together with the UJ School of Agriculture. Besides, selecting 22 eligible participants from 5 organizations working on different agricultural, water and forest aspects. The involved local institutions were: NARC, MoA, MoWI, RBG and RSCN.
2. Delivering the training (TMT) in Jordan- completed Two staff members of ITC ran a nine working days course related to the use of UAV and satellite RS in agriculture, water and forestry. The course included topics such as introduction to agriculture and forestry Remote Sensing and UAV Applications, flight planning and processing UAV images, crops mapping and monitoring, forest fires mapping and monitoring, among others. The course had lectures, practical and discussion sessions. Besides, the course included a one-day demonstration for data collection using UAV in Ajloun Forest Reserve area. Furthermore, the ITC and UJ staff members ran a workshop regarding the development of materials to include satellite and UAV RS into the curriculum of the School of Agriculture.
3. Implementation of satellite and UAV RS learned knowledge on the ground and university curriculum development (completed) Six ongoing case studies were chosen by the participants according to the interest and needs of their organizations, in which they applied the skills and the knowledge gained from the training on the ground. However, only three full case studies were completed, and the other two were relatively well prepared that reflects the acquired knowledge and skills. One case study could not be applied due to Covid19 situation. For more explanation, please check the external factors and risks section. The Dutch experts provided ongoing support at a distance to the partners from Jordan, including but not limited to, organizing regular online meetings..
4. Follow-up, dissemination, and sustainability mission (completed) Due to COVID-19, it became impossible for the Dutch experts to travel to Jordan to conduct the third phase of the project in person. So we adapted the case studies supervision and following up to an online format, where regular virtual meetings were provided by the ITC staff members. Furthermore, due to the same reason, the open day was also cancelled and replaced by a webinar to increase the awareness, represent the project and the main outputs.
**The main outcomes of the project are:**
• Five case studies are implemented and reflected UAV and RS technologies' potential to create ecologically sustainable food systems and better water management. The five case studies are:
- CASE STUDY 1: Can remotely-sensed data detect plant physiology indicators in Ajloun forest reserve?. Team: The University of Jordan- collaborated with the Rangers) & RSCN - CASE STUDY 2: Use of remote sensing to studying the impact of delaying rainfall on the Vegetative Cover at Al-Karak Governorate. Team: NARC - CASE STUDY 3: Use of remote sensing (aerial and satellite data) in forest fire management in Jarash, Jordan. Team: MoA - Department of Forestry collaborated with UJ & Rangers - CASE STUDY 4 : Mapping and analysis of vegetation cover patterns and changes in the Royal Botanical Garden (RBG) using satellite images. Team: RBG and MoWI - CASE STUDY 5 : Measuring the change of forest area at Ajloun Forest Reserve and its surroundings using NDVI . Team: RSCN
Please find as an attachment the summary for the case studies.
• Six organizations were strengthened by individual and group training on Remote Sensing applications for sustainable food and water management systems, where The TMT approached participants from different governmental and non-governmental institutions working on different agricultural, forest and water aspects.
• In total 22 people were trained from the six organizations, whereas the original target was 20 participants.
• Six organizations were strengthened by establishing a collaboration network among them. Besides existing collaborations, three new MoUs formal collaboration have been established.
• One pilot at least to be trained form the UJ by the Rangers following the collaboration letter which was signed on 4 January 2021.
• Increased awareness and dissemination of the results by organizing a webinar with around 65 attendees and distributing the recording to 142 registrations
• Paved the way to create an enabling environment for UAVs through the MoUs with the Rangers, the webinar and by bringing the different organizations together.
**Related to Jordan university – School of Agriculture :**
• Two new curricula for revised courses were developed and taught: Forestry and Farm Machinery& technology. 109 students in newly revised study programs graduated in December 2020, and 13 graduated in Summer 2020.
• One new course to be developed and taught in 2021 ( Precision Agricultural)- 300 graduates per academic year
• Established stronger collaboration with the UT, other public and NGOs institutions in Jordan.
• Two research methodologies were implemented in the case studies, and two joint publications between organizations are planned to be published.
• 1 MoU with the Rangers, and 3 MoUs re-activated with MoA, NARC, and RSCN

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: 18 participants did the project evaluation and 20 the project management survey, more than 75 % agree or highly agree with the organizational , the duration of the project, and the learned knowledge during the project, and more than 80% agreed to the amount and the provided support from the staff members by the UJ and ITC.

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: Done- A clear and direct invitation have been delivered to the institutional partners. The invitation clearly gave priority and encouraged women participation. In the selection of participants for the training, women were also be prioritized. It was done with some deviation due to the outbreak of Covid19. - specifically, invite women to the UAV Open Day, which is replaced by the webinar, invitation has been sent specifically to females in different organizations. - Travel costs for ten women participants in UAV day - could not be implemented. However, there were 142 registrations in the webinar, from which 62 % were females. Besides, the video recording of the webinar was sent to all the registered emails. Furthermore, one of the case studies was done by women participants.

title.narrative: B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: During the selection of the final group of participants, priorities have been given to those from outside Amman and from rural areas. Therefore, seats were given for the ten eligible participants with less financial and logistic abilities to attend this TMT. Furthermore, the TMT has offered them transportation and midday meal support. The support was provided only during the nine-days training, as the follow-up visit was cancelled due to the outbreak of Covid19, and the activities were adapted to an online format.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: One participant from the Exporters and Producers Association for Fruit and Vegetables (JEPA)(NGO) has dropped out after the first day of the TMT. Replacement from the same organization could not be arranged in a short notice. The involved local institutions were four public and two NGOs

title.narrative: B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: Participants are still employed by their organizations and did not change their job.

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: The TMT training supported one female staff member from UJ to apply for the professorship and one male from MOW to become the head of the department.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: The level of the applied acquired knowledge within the working environment is varied from one participant to another. it is worth mentioning that all the six involved institutions in the TMT training contributed/participated in the case studies.

title.narrative: B.O.3. Number of organisations with institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: The six involved institutions in the TMT varied in their institutional mechanism for quality assurance.

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: The target was 10 women. But we had 7 women in the TMT project

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 10-03-2021: The target was 20 but we had 22 participants.

title.narrative: B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy

comment.narrative: 12-04-2021: Gender strategy includes females having equitable access to the training/education and building an internal and external network that helps them excel in their careers. The TMT emphasized women participation from the beginning of the project. Through this training, seven women from four different organizations out of six organizations participated in the project, had access to the training, and fruitful collaboration with the other participants in the case studies.

title.narrative: B.I.5. % of scholarships awarded to minorities
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: Not applicable for this TMT- In Jordan, women and men have equal rights in terms of education, ownership, leadership among others. Thus, gender related issues were not to be especially prevalent during the project. However, the participation of women has been emphasized as explained in the previous indicators

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: The indicator can be seen through: • The collaboration between the participants in the training and the ongoing case studies. • The reactivation of the existing MoUs and establishing new ones between organizations • The UAV orientation workshop which was done by the Rangers to the staff members from the school agriculture/UJ • The MoUs between the Rangers and UJ increased the UJ contribution in the environmental issues on the country level
